required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: A Comparison of Direct vs. Video-laryngoscopes for Different Emergency Pediatric Airway Scenarios

brief_summary.textblock: The effectiveness of endotracheal intubation in pre-hospital conditions is insufficient - especially in the context of pediatric patients. Anatomical differences in pediatric patients compared to adults: a relative larger tongue, a larger and more flabby epiglottis - located more cephalously - that make intubation is more difficult than for adults. Also, higher oxygen metabolism requires the immediate response of medical personnel to children in case of need to protect the airways and support breath.

primary_outcome.description: time in seconds required for a successful intubation attempt

secondary_outcome.description: If the oesopharyngeal tube was incorrectly placed or intubation lasted longer than 60 seconds, the airway-management attempt was defined as a failure.
self-reported percentage the vocal cord visualization using the Cormack-Lehane grading, scale developed by Cormack and Lehane, based on four degrees of visibility of the glottis.

secondary_outcome.measure: POGO score - percentage of glottic opening
secondary_outcome.description: self-reported percentage the vocal cord visualization. A 100% POGO score is a full view of the glottis from the anterior commissure to the interarytenoid notch. A POGO score of 0 means that even the interarytenoid notch is not seen.
participants were asked which method of ETI they would prefer in a real-life resuscitation.
self-reported percentage the vocal cord visualization. A 100% score is a extremely difficult procedure. A Ease of use score of 1% means that procedure is extremely easy

arm_group.description: intubation in the tongue edema scenario. Tongue edema was obtain using simulator indicators

arm_group.arm_group_label: Spinal immobilization with normal airway scenario
arm_group.description: intubation in spinal immobilization with normal airway scenario

arm_group.arm_group_label: Spinal immobilization with tongue edema scenario
arm_group.description: endotracheal intubation with immobilized cervical spine and tongue edema scenario

intervention.description: intubation will be performed using standard direct laryngoscopy - Macintosh laryngoscope
intervention.arm_group_label: Spinal immobilization with normal airway scenario
Spinal immobilization with tongue edema scenario

intervention.description: intubation will be performed using Miller laryngoscope
intervention.arm_group_label: Spinal immobilization with normal airway scenario
Spinal immobilization with tongue edema scenario

intervention.description: intubation will be performed using McGrath MAC EMS video - laryngoscope
intervention.arm_group_label: Spinal immobilization with normal airway scenario
Spinal immobilization with tongue edema scenario

intervention.description: intubation will be performed using GlideScope video - laryngoscope
intervention.arm_group_label: Spinal immobilization with normal airway scenario
Spinal immobilization with tongue edema scenario

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- paramedics
- give voluntary consent to participate in the study
- none experience in videolaryngoscopy
- less than 1 year experience in medicine
Exclusion Criteria:
- not meet the above criteria
- wrist or low back diseases

reference.citation: Szarpak Ł, Karczewska K, Czyżewski Ł, Truszewski Z, Kurowski A. Airtraq Laryngoscope Versus the Conventional Macintosh Laryngoscope During Pediatric Intubation Performed by Nurses: A Randomized Crossover Manikin Study With Three Airway Scenarios. Pediatr Emerg Care. 2017 Nov;33(11):735-739. doi: 10.1097/PEC.0000000000000741.

Madziala M, Smereka J, Dabrowski M, Leung S, Ruetzler K, Szarpak L. A comparison of McGrath MAC® and standard direct laryngoscopy in simulated immobilized cervical spine pediatric intubation: a manikin study. Eur J Pediatr. 2017 Jun;176(6):779-786. doi: 10.1007/s00431-017-2909-9. Epub 2017 Apr 21.

Szarpak L, Kurowski A, Czyzewski L, Rodríguez-Núñez A. Video rigid flexing laryngoscope (RIFL) vs Miller laryngoscope for tracheal intubation during pediatric resuscitation by paramedics: a simulation study. Am J Emerg Med. 2015 Aug;33(8):1019-24. doi: 10.1016/j.ajem.2015.04.054. Epub 2015 Apr 30.

patient_data.ipd_description: data will be available from the main investigator
